title-group.article-title: Does Stock Liquidity Affect Incentives to Monitor? Evidence from Corporate Takeovers

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© 2014 The Society for Financial Studies

abstract.p: We test whether stock liquidity affects acquirer returns through its hypothesized effect on institutional monitoring. We find that firms with lower stock liquidity have higher acquirer gains for takeovers of private targets, but not for takeovers of public targets. The negative relation between liquidity and acquirer gains is stronger when the threat of disciplinary trading (exit) by institutions is weaker and acquirers have higher agency costs. Acquirers of private targets with lower stock liquidity are more likely to withdraw deals and experience higher involuntary CEO turnover following value-destroying acquisitions. Our results support the hypothesis that stock liquidity weakens institutions' incentives to monitor management decisions, except in those cases where the disciplining effect of the threat of exit may be particularly high.

p.mixed-citation: We do not view these results as consistent with a positive effect of stock liquidity on monitoring via voice (e.g., Faure-Grimaud and Gromb 2004), given that we find a negative relation between liquidity and announcement returns for private acquisitions and that there is no theoretical prediction of the positive effect of liquidity on voice being stronger in specific contexts, such as value-destroying acquisitions, as there is with the threat of exit models.
Note, though, that for a complete test of some of the other theories (e.g., Maug 1998) we would need an empirical setup in which liquidity and institutional ownership are estimated jointly.

Typically, this concern is addressed by employing an instrumental variable approach. Fang, Noe, and Tice (2009), Fang, Tian, and Tice (2012), Bharath, Jayaraman, and Nager (2013), and Edmans, Fang, and Zur (2013) use decimalization of stock prices as an instrument, but this is not feasible in our setting because ours is a cross-sectional rather than a time-series analysis.

Fang, Tian, and Tice (2012) show that firm innovation diminishes with higher stock liquidity as ownership by short-term oriented institutions increases. Note that their result is not inconsistent with exit models in which blockholders are considered long-term institutions that have the option to exit in the short run, but will not exit if managers maximize shareholder value.

We follow the definition first introduced by Bushee (1998), and further developed in Bushee (2001), who uses principal component analysis based on a large number of variables for this classification. An institution is labeled transient if it belongs to the group with higher share turnover and less concentrated holdings. These data are kindly made available by Brian Bushee on his website (http://acct3.wharton.upenn.edu/faculty/bushee/).

A number of alternative measures of liquidity have been used in the literature. However, the theories on the effect of liquidity on institutional monitoring imply that large shareholders are mostly concerned with the price impact of their trades (e.g., Maug 1998), which is well captured by the Amihud (2002) measure (Goyenko, Holden, and Trzcinka 2009). In addition, to the extent that the Amihud (2002) measure captures trading costs or price informativeness, it can also be used to test the prediction in Admati and Pfleiderer (2009) of a negative relation between trading costs and institutional monitoring, and the prediction in Faure-Grimaud and Gromb (2004) of a positive relation between price informativeness and institutional monitoring.

Given that, theoretically, illiquidity could be zero, the correct functional form is debatable. We therefore also follow Chordia, Huh, and Subrahmanyam (2009) and Hasbrouck (1999, 2009) and employ a square root transformation as a robustness check, and we find similar results. More details are provided in Section 4 of the paper.
We also consider a variable for the percentage of equity used in the transactions and an all-equity indicator variable for pure equity deals and obtain similar results.

Execucomp collects as many as nine executives for a given year, with most firms reporting five. Hence, per company, one could obtain several entries, depending on how many executives a company files in its proxy statement.

When we estimate model (4) conditional on the availability of CEO Incentives, we find Stock Liquidity to be insignificant, with a p-value similar to that in model (5). Adding CEO Incentives to the full sample regression decreases the proportion of acquisitions of private targets. As shown in the next section, the coefficient on stock liquidity remains significant at the 5% level when we add CEO Incentives to the specification for the sample of acquisitions of private targets.

A private cost in this context may be the effort needed to screen out targets and negotiate better acquisition terms. This private cost also exists in public acquisitions, but can be offset by the increased visibility and size (and possibly compensation) that come with a public acquisition.
Admati and Pfleiderer (2009) mention value-reducing mergers as an empirical example that corresponds to the type of agency problem where the threat of exit is expected to be particularly effective.

Ferreira, Ferreira, and Raposo (2011) measure price informativeness as the firm-specific stock return variation calculated as the log (1 -R2/R2) where R2 is obtained from a regression regressing daily stock returns on the daily returns of a value-weighted market index and asset-pricing factors. We use a period ending 46 days before the announcement date with a minimum of 100 trading days and a maximum of 200 trading days. The three asset-pricing factors we use are Fama and French's (1992) Small minus Big (SMB) and High minus Low (HML) factors and the Carhart (1997) momentum factor.
The mean (median) number of nontransient blockholders in the complete sample of acquisitions of private targets is 1.66 (1.00) with 584 observations with zero blockholders.

Alternatively, we use the magnitude of exit, measured as the number of shares sold by the largest blockholder as a percentage of the total number of shares outstanding as the dependent variable. The coefficient on acquirer stock liquidity for OLS specifications for the subsample of value-destroying deals is 0.024, but statistically indistinguishable from zero (p-value = 0.268). The results for the OLS exit regressions are available upon request. We thank the referee for suggesting the exit tests.
We thank the referee for pointing this out.

The empirical design in Parrino, Sias, and Starks (2003) is different from ours. They condition their sample on CEO turnover and find that, prior to the forced CEO's departure, institutions on average sell shares. In our design, we attempt to explain forced CEO departures through a shock (a value-destroying acquisition).
We are very grateful to Dirk Jenter, Fadi Kanaan, Florian Peters, and Alexander Wagner for sharing with us their hand-collected data on involuntary CEO turnover.
We cannot run meaningful analyses of the partition based on the Number of Blockholders, as in previous subsections, because of the far fewer observations for which we have CEO turnover information.
